EmailTemplate.subject: Expanding health equity through virtual care
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
Virtual care provides real value for the most vulnerable If virtual care seems like a luxury, it’s not. In fact, a peer-reviewed study of people with diabetes suggests that when these programs are designed to consider an individual’s health literacy level, the barriers to care they may be facing and an understanding of their coaching needs, social determinants of health do not appear to hinder high program engagement.1 And, of course, higher engagement can lead to improved health and blood glucose measures. Americans in rural communities report more chronic conditions and describe themselves in poorer health than urban residents.2
Health equity <[[https://business.teladochealth.com/resources/article/a-four-pronged-approach-to-addressing-health-inequity/?&utm_source=marketo&utm_medium=email&utm_content=baseline&utm_term=hp&utm_campaign=dgn-education&utm_campaign_id=in-text]]> is a complex issue with no simple solution. An effort this large requires systemic change, with organizations working together to achieve health equity for a better society and a better world.
